ja:head.ce:title: Detailed multi-dimensional study on NO x formation and destruction mechanisms in dimethyl ether/air diffusion flame under the moderate or intense low-oxygen dilution (MILD) condition

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para:
In this paper, the moderate or intense low-oxygen dilution (MILD) technology was employed to reduce NO x emission index of the DME flame, whose NO x emission was expected high due to its higher adiabatic flame temperature. Experiments and modeling were conducted to study NO x emission mechanism of the DME-MILD jet diffusion flame. Various co-flow temperatures
(
T
c o
∗
)
and oxygen concentrations
(
X
O 2
∗
)
were involved to investigate dependence of NO x emission mechanism on hot dilution level. NO x formation pathway in all subzones was clarified, employing the reaction path and sensitivity analyses. The results showed that for the DME-MILD jet flame, NO x was generated mainly through the NNH and N 2O pathways, which was rather different from the traditional DME jet diffusion flame. EI
NOx increased gradually with the increment in
X
O 2
∗
or
T
c o
∗
. A strong NO NO 2 conversion process and ultra-clean performance were verified for the DME-MILD jet flame.

ce:list-item.ce:para: A coaxial jet burner with hot diluted co-flow was used to model the MILD condition.
NO x emission process has been predicted by CFD-CRN method with detailed kinetics.
NO x of DME-MILD flame was generated mainly via N 2O- and NNH-intermediate pathways.
NO x emission decreased with increase in co-flow temperature or oxygen concentration.
Ultra-clean performance of the DME-MILD flame has been validated.

ce:section.ce:para: As one of the most competitive clean alternative candidates, dimethyl ether (DME, CH 3OCH 3) has gained increasing attentions in the past few years. Studies proved its superior performances in ignition [1,2], emission [3,4], and efficiency over the traditional fuels [5–10], which enables its significant potential to substitute for the liquefied petroleum gas (LPG), diesel, and liquefied natural gas (LNG) [11,12].

About 70% of China's total energy consumption is provided by coal combustion, which has produced millions of tons of pollutants to the atmosphere and environment which are very harmful for human beings and the eco-system. An effective way to solve this problem is to convert coal to clean gaseous fuels before combustion, such as hydrocarbons, alcohol, and ethers etc. DME is a promising clean alternative fuel which can be produced from coal efficiently by the gasification process [13]. So the coal-derived DME is very meaningful for China, in terms of environmental protection or national energy security [14].

Because of the excellent atomization and ignition properties of the liquid DME [15,16], fairly low emissions of soot particles, unburned hydrocarbon (HC), CO, and acoustic noise generation associated with DME were reported in the literature [5–8,17–19]. DME is regarded as a more suitable fuel for the compression-ignition (CI) engines as a neat fuel or fuel additive. This is not only because of its lower auto-ignition temperature and instantaneous vaporization after injection into the cylinder, but also because of the high oxygen content (35 wt%) and absence of C C bonds in its molecular structure. Besides, DME has also been applied to industrial boiler [20–25] and gas turbine [26,27].

The moderate or intense low-oxygen dilution (MILD) combustion, which belongs to the flameless combustion, is a promising combustion technology and has gained increasing attentions in the recent years. The basic reaction conditions of MILD combustion are that the initial reactant temperature is above the self-ignition temperature of the mixture and the temperature rise due to combustion is lower than the mixture's self-ignition temperature [28,29]. Generally, in the practical MILD system, a fraction of combustion products are often recirculated and mixed with the initial reactants to generate a hot diluted atmosphere. In this regime, the recirculated products mix with the fresh reactants in the flame base rapidly within the limited ignition delay time, forming the reactant mixture with high temperature and low oxygen concentration before the distributed auto-ignition occurs [30,31].

In the MILD regime, the specific heat of the combustion products increases. Hence, both the flame temperature and temperature rise across the whole reaction zone decrease, which further leads to depression of NO x formation. In addition, chemical reaction rates are also depressed because of the low oxygen concentration and reduced flame temperature. As a result, the reaction zone enlarges and occupies almost the whole combustion chamber, and reactions are highly distributed. The relevant studies indicated that the MILD combustion is promising with features of extremely-low NO x and CO emissions, higher thermal efficiency, and lower noise generation.

The previous studies using the conventional fuels, like methane [32,33], syngas [34,35], and coal [36] etc., showed that NO x and CO emission indices could be reduced significantly in the MILD regime. Hence, it is expected that the DME-MILD flame may yield ultra-clean performance. This is particularly meaningful for the DME flame which usually emits a high level of NO x due to its enhanced adiabatic temperature. Additionally, considering the much lower auto-ignition temperature of DME (235 °C) versus the traditional fuels, the critical flue gas recirculation ratio required to achieve the MILD combustion of DME will be much smaller than that of the traditional fuels, which facilitates the realization of MILD combustion for DME particularly.

However, NO x emission mechanism of DME in the MILD condition was not studied as thoroughly. In this paper, experiments and modeling are conducted on a lab-scale burner to investigate NO x emission mechanism of the DME-MILD jet flame. The CFD-CRN method [20,23,37–39], which enables detailed NO x mechanism and high computational efficiency, is employed to reveal the key NO x reaction pathways and dominant elementary reactions in different subzones of the flame. The effects of co-flow temperature and oxygen concentration on NO x formation are also addressed. The findings of this study may be valuable for the engineering design or operation of the DME-MILD combustion system.

The CFD-CRN method [20,23,37–39], which indeed decouples NO x prediction from CFD modeling, can improve the computational efficiency significantly, while make less concession to prediction accuracy. It had been utilized in one of our previous studies [40] to successfully reveal the NO x and CO emission mechanism of the DME jet diffusion flame. The CFD-CRN method runs in three steps: (I) performing the CFD calculation with an accurate turbulence model but skeletal chemical kinetics to obtain the basic information of flow, temperature or mixture fraction distribution, etc. (II) Applying an appropriate algorithm on the converged CFD solution, grouping or lumping the neighboring cells with similar characteristics to generate an ensemble of chemical reactors. The initial input data for the chemical reactor network (CRN) iteration, including temperature in each reactor as well as mass flow rates between the adjacent reactors, are calculated from the CFD solution. (III) Solving the CRN with detailed NO x chemical kinetics to obtain the detailed information of pollutant formation/destruction in each reactor.

The experimental apparatus and coaxial jet burner employed currently had been presented in details in our previous study [24]. They are only described briefly in this part. As shown in Fig. 1 , cool DME issued from a stainless-steel water-cooled fuel nozzle (internal diameter 3.00 mm), and hot diluted co-flow issued from the outer annular tube (internal diameter 100 mm). During the experiments, the hot diluted co-flow was produced by mixing the streams of O 2, N 2, CO 2, and H 2O, which were heated by an electric heater before mixing. The flow rates of these streams were regulated properly, making the mixture composition identical with the practical combustion product of DME at a certain equivalence ratio. There were several measuring ports with 50 mm in vertical distance along the left and right furnace walls, serving as accesses for the temperature and species measurements.

During the tests, the fuel jet velocity and its temperature were fixed at 300 K and 15 m/s respectively; the co-flow velocity was kept at 10 m/s. As listed in Table 1 , several co-flow temperatures

During the measurements, several unshielded K- and B-type thermocouples, as well as a MGA5 type infrared gas analyzer and a gas-phase spectrograph, were employed to measure the axial and radial profiles of temperature and species mole fractions, respectively. The measured temperature data were corrected using the approach of Roberts et al. [41] to reduce the measuring error resulting from heat loss from thermocouple bead to the cool ambient. Table 2 shows technical parameters of the MGA5 type gas analyzer and gas-phase spectrograph, respectively.

The CFD modeling was completed using the software ANSYS FLUENT [42]. The Favre-averaged mass, momentum, energy, radiative intensity, species, turbulent kinetic energy ( k) and its dissipation rate ( ε) transport equations were iterated, as Ref. [25] did.

As illustrated in Fig. 2 a, only a quarter of the furnace volume was meshed, generating 575832 hexahedral cells in total. Fig. 2b displays the mesh on the slice x = 0 mm, as well as the input boundary conditions as specified in Table 3 .

As Fig. 3 shows, the predicted temperature and flow fields for case 1 using the current mesh coincided well with those predicted using another finer mesh consisting of 884227 cells, which indicated that the current mesh could guarantee the grid-independency.
Additionally, a skeletal DME chemical mechanism containing 30 species [43], which was reduced from a detailed DME mechanism proposed by Zhao et al. [44], was used for the CFD simulation.

As Figs. 4 and 5
show, gas temperatures were slightly over-predicted because of the inevitable heat loss of thermocouple bead during the experiments, especially in the high-temperature region. In overall, the CFD simulation agreed reasonably well with the experimental data. Hence, the current CFD calculation could reproduce the experimental behavior accurately.

Firstly, the neighboring cells with similar behaviors were lumped, creating a number of equivalent chemical reactors. These reactors, as well as the internal temperature and mass flow rate of each reactor, constitute a CRN which can represent the fluid dynamics inside the furnace adequately. This will provide a possibility of utilizing a detailed NO x chemical kinetics to calculate the concerned important chemical reactions inside the flame.

The CRN was constructed based on the local equivalence ratio ( Φ
local , as formula (2) defines), rather than gas temperature, considering homogeneity of temperature distribution in the MILD condition. The meaning of each item in formula (2) is explained in the Nomenclature table.

The CRN was developed in two steps. First, the whole computational domain was separated into four regions: the fuel-rich zone (FRZ, Φ
local > 1.5), diffusion flamelet zone (DFZ, Φ
local = 0.5–1.5), co-flow zone (CFZ, Φ
local < 0.5, straight streamline), and recirculation zone (RZ, Φ
local < 0.5, backflow streamline), as Fig. 6 a illustrates. Second, the criteria shown in Table 4 were applied to each subregion to generate a number of perfectly stirred reactors (PSRs). Selection of PSR as the equivalent reactor was attributed to the feature that the chemical reaction time scale is much larger than the species mixing time scale because of depression of chemical reaction rates in the MILD regime, which agrees with the nature of PSR [33].

The reaction temperature in each PSR was estimated as the mass-averaged cell temperature of the PSR. Moreover, the reactive volume of each PSR

A detailed DME mechanism developed by Zhao et al. [44] was combined with the GRI 3.0 NO x submechanism [46], to describe the NO x formation and destruction mechanisms of the DME-MILD flame.

In summary, the basic input data for CRN solution including the temperature, reactive volume, mass flow rates and mass splitting factors ( R
r,j ) of each PSR were obtained from the CFD-predicted solution. In the CRN solution procedure, the mass and species conservation equations were iterated to obtain mole fractions of all species in each PSR.

As Figs. 7 and 8
display, the CRN-predicted species mole fractions (including NO x) coincided fairly well with the experimental data, verifying that the CFD-CRN method could reproduce the emission characteristics of DME-MILD flame accurately.

ce:section.ce:section-title: NO x concentration and reaction rate characteristics of the DME-MILD jet flame
ce:section.ce:para:
As shown in Fig. 10, several subzones are defined herein. The high-temperature DFZ located along the stoichiometric iso-contour is divided into upstream diffusion flamelet zone (UDFL, located within z/d
f = 0–100, d
f = 3 mm is the fuel nozzle diameter) and downstream diffusion flamelet zone (DDFL, located within z/d
f = 100–280). The FRZ is divided into FRZ1 and FRZ2. FRZ1 is featured with negative NO reaction rates and positive NO 2 reaction rates, while FRZ2 is featured with positive NO reaction rates and negative NO 2 reaction rates. The annular zone outside of DDFL is designated as ADDFL ( Φ
local = 0.3–0.5, z/d
f = 100–305), which has positive NO reaction rates and negative NO 2 reaction rates. The region downstream of DDFL is denoted as the post-flame zone (PFZ) where temperature dropped quickly and reactions ceased basically. The region outside of UDFL is designated as CFZ1. The recirculation zone featured with backflow streamlines and the lowest temperatures is denoted as RZ. The criteria for definition of the subzones are summarized in Table 5 .

Figs. 9a and 10 a illustrate that in the DME-MILD jet flame, NO was mainly produced in UDFL and ADDFL, with the largest NO formation rate occurring in UDFL where had the highest temperature ( Fig. 6a). In the inner FRZs and outer RZ, NO concentration was rather ignorable. In CFZ, NO profile was rather homogenous, due to the uniformity of temperature. On the contrary, NO 2 was mainly generated in RZ and PFZ.

Fig. 10b indicates that the largest NO 2 formation and consumption rates were located at FRZ1 and ADDFL, respectively. The formation rates of NO 2 in PFZ and RZ were moderate. Compared with RZ, FRZ1 made a less contribution to the overall NO 2 production because of the much smaller volume of FRZ1, although the highest NO 2 formation rates occurred in it.

In DME-MILD jet flame, NO x formation rate was generally 2–3 orders of magnitudes lower than that of the DME jet diffusion flame [37,38], since temperature rise in the MILD regime was significantly depressed [34]. Furthermore, the NO x profile was much more homogenous because of the uniformity of gas temperature [34].

Additionally, Figs. 9 and 10 indicate that NO and NO 2 varied in the opposite trends in many subareas, which implies that there existed a strong NO NO 2 interchange in the flame. For examples, in FRZ1, PFZ, and RZ, NO was consumed, producing the same moles of NO 2; while in FRZ2, CFZ1, and ADDFL, NO 2 was converted to NO. However in DDFL, both NO and NO 2 were consumed. This indicates that the interchange among the N-containing species inside the DME-MILD flame was rather complicated. In the next part, the reaction path and sensitivity analyses are performed to further reveal NO x formation and destruction mechanisms in all subzones.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Formation and consumption mechanisms in different subzones of the DME-MILD jet flame
ce:section.ce:para: Table 6 lists the key elementary reactions of the five NO formation pathways available in the GRI 3.0 NO x mechanism [46], i.e. the thermal (or Zeldovich), prompt (or Fenimore), N 2O-, NO 2 , and NNH-intermediate paths.

(I) Formation of thermal NO starts from oxidation of the atmospheric N 2 via reaction (R1), which is important at T > 1800 K. Then the products N of (R1) combine with O 2 or OH, producing another amount of thermal NO via (R2) and (R3). (II) The prompt pathway is dominated in the fuel-rich zone, where N 2 can react with available hydrocarbon radicals (mainly CH), producing HCN which will be further oxidized to NO via a few reactions. (III) The N 2O-intermediate NO is produced by oxidation of the intermediate N 2O. Reactions (R5)-(R7) are responsible for its formation, and (R8)-(R10) are for its destruction. (IV) The NO 2-intermediate pathway ((R13) and (R14)) is responsible for conversion from NO 2 to NO, and the reverse NO 2-intermediate pathway ((R11) and (R12)) is responsible for conversion from NO to NO 2. (V) In the NNH-intermediate mechanism, (R15)-(R18) supply the precursor NNH, which is further transformed into NO via (R19). (VI) The NO x reburning mechanism becomes important in the low-temperature and fuel-rich area. The combination of NO and CH
i produces HCN, which can be finally reduced to N 2 via further reactions. It should be noted that all the pathways are coupled with each other, rather than independent, since the reactants or products of one pathway usually participate in the others.

Besides, the sensitivity analysis [47] with normalized sensitivity index ( NSI
i ) was performed to identify the controlling elementary reactions in each subzone. NSI
i which varies within [-1, 1] can evaluate the relative importance of each reaction to NO production.
(7)

The reaction path ( Fig. 11 ) and sensitivity ( Fig. 12 ) analyses revealed that NO x was produced/consumed through distinct pathways in different subzones, as Table 7 summarizes.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Conversion from NO to NO 2 via the reverse NO 2 pathway in the low-temperature ( T < 1100 K) zones, including FRZ1, PFZ, and RZ
ce:section.ce:para: Fig. 11a indicates that in FRZ1, reaction rate of the reverse NO 2 pathway surpassed that of the NO 2 pathway, such that a large amount of NO was converted to NO 2.

Table 8 lists kinetic parameters of the key reactions of the NO 2 (R13, R14) and reverse NO 2-pathways (R11, R12). According to the Arrhenius law [47], both the forward reaction rates of (R13) and (R14) increase with temperature because of their positive E
ai , which implies that the NO 2 pathway becomes important at high temperature. On the contrary, the forward reaction rates of (R11) and (R12) decrease with temperature, due to the negative β
i of (R11) and negative E
ai of (R12). Consequently, in FRZ1 with very low temperatures and abundant HO 2 radical, NO could be transformed to NO 2 via the reverse NO 2 pathway. It should be noted that the initial reactant NO in FRZ1 came from UDFL by inward diffusion, rather than from chemical reactions.

Additionally, in FRZ1, the N 2O-intermediate pathway produced a small amount of N 2O, a marginal fraction of which was oxidized to NO. A small fraction of NO was reduced to HNO and NH through the reverse prompt pathway. The contribution of each pathway was calculated by integrating the NO reaction rate of each pathway across all PSRs in a certain subzone. The results indicated that in FRZ1, contribution of the N 2O-intermediate and reverse prompt pathways weighted about 2.1% and 0.5% of the reverse NO 2 pathway respectively.
The dominance of reverse NO 2 pathway in FRZ1 can also be revealed by Fig. 12, which shows that the NO reaction rate was most sensitive to reaction (R12).

Similarly, in the low-temperature zones ZR and PFZ, a considerable fraction of NO was converted to NO 2 via the reverse NO 2 pathway. This was responsible for the peak NO 2 concentration in the upstream area of RZ ( z = 0–200 mm, T < 700 K), as Fig. 9 shows.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Conversion from NO 2 to NO via the NO 2 pathways in the moderate-temperature ( T = 1100–1300 K) zones, including FRZ2 and CFZ1
ce:section.ce:para: In FRZ2 with increasing temperature, the forward reaction rates of (R11) and (R12) should decrease, while those of (R13) and (R14) should increase, as explained previously. Thus, the NO 2 pathway was activated. Figs. 11b and 12 show that reaction (R13) is responsible for dominance of the NO 2 pathway in FRZ2.

In addition, due to the increments in gas temperature and radical concentrations in FRZ2, the N 2O, NNH, and prompt pathways as well as the reburning chemistry also tended to be activated. However since the temperatures in FRZ2 were moderate (1100–1300 K), contributions of these pathways were not as comparable as that of the NO 2 pathway. It was analyzed that contributions for the N 2O, NNH, prompt, and reburning pathways were 1.1%, 0.3%, 0.7%, and 2.5% of that for the NO 2 pathway, respectively.

The NO 2 pathway was also dominated in CFZ1. Similarly, the initial reactant NO 2 of the NO 2-pathway chemistry in CFZ1 originated from the outer RZ by inward diffusion, rather than from chemical reactions.

ce:section.ce:section-title: NO reduction via the reverse prompt and reburning pathways, as well as production via the N 2O and NNH pathways in the high-temperature ( T = 1300–1700 K) DDFL
ce:section.ce:para: Fig. 11c illustrates that in DDFL with the highest temperature, reaction rate of each pathway was enhanced significantly. NO was generated mainly through the NO 2, N 2O, and NNH pathways.

In addition, the availability of reactive radicals and hydrocarbons in DDFL also enabled accelerations of the reverse prompt and reburning pathways significantly. As a result, the NO consumption rate via the reverse prompt and reburning pathways surpassed its production rate through the NO 2, N 2O, and NNH pathways. Consequently, the net reaction rate of NO became negative in DDFL, as displayed in Fig. 10a.

ce:section.ce:section-title: NO formation via the NO 2, N 2O, thermal, and prompt pathways in the high-temperature ( T = 1300–1700 K) UDFL
ce:section.ce:para: Fig. 11d indicates that in the high-temperature UDFL, the NO 2, N 2O, thermal, and prompt pathways made the major contributions to NO formation. The reaction rate analysis demonstrated that contributions of these pathways to the overall NO formation were 60.1%, 34.9%, 2.6%, and 2.4%, respectively.

The dominance of the NO 2 pathway is attributed to the high-temperatures in UDFL and its short distance to the upstream RZ, where is rich in the initial reactant NO 2, as Fig. 9b shows. This agreed well with the largest NSI
i of (R13) and (R14) in Fig. 12. The abundance of O radical and third bodies is responsible for the dominance of N 2O pathway in UDFL, as reactions (R5) and (R8) indicate. Due to the depressed temperatures in the MILD regime, importances of the thermal and prompt pathways were much less than the NO 2 and N 2O pathways, as Fig. 12 shows.

ce:section.ce:section-title: NO formation via the NO 2, N 2O, NNH, and prompt pathways in the ADDFL
ce:section.ce:para: Figs. 11e and 12 demonstrate that the NO 2, N 2O, NNH, and prompt pathways were dominated in ADDFL. Contributions of them to the overall NO production were 42.7%, 20.2%, 25.0%, and 12.1% respectively. The dominance of the NO 2 pathway was responsible for formation of NO and destruction of NO 2 in ADDFL, as Fig. 10 shows.

As Fig. 11e shows, the reactant HCN of the prompt pathway was not produced through (R4), but mainly through the reverse prompt pathway in the upstream regions. Specifically, as Fig. 11a–d shows, in the upstream zones FRZ1, FRZ2, UDFL, and DDFL, a partial fraction of NO was reduced to HCN, HNO, NH, and NH 2 via the reverse prompt way. After flowing into the ADDFL, these species were oxidized back to NO via the prompt pathway. Since the moles of nitrogen were conserved during this conversion process, the prompt pathway, indeed, contributed rather little to the overall NO formation.

Similarly, the NO 2 pathway also did not make a contribution to the overall NO x (=NO + NO 2) formation, since the moles of nitrogen were conserved during the NO NO 2 inter-conversion process. However, it changed fractions of NO and NO 2 in the NO x mixture.

In addition, the unimportant NSI
i of (R1)-(R3) in each PSR ( Fig. 12) indicate that contribution of the thermal pathway to the overall NO x emission was also ignorable. As a result, in the DME-MILD jet flames inside the furnace, NO x generation via the NNH and N 2O intermediate pathways in each subzone amounted to the final emission index of NO x. This was significantly different from the traditional DME jet diffusion flame, for which the thermal and prompt pathways were dominated [38,39].

ce:section.ce:section-title: NO x emission index of the DME-MILD jet diffusion flame
ce:section.ce:para:
The measured and predicted NO x emission index ( EI
NOx = EI
NO + EI
NO2 ) of cases 1–6, as well as the contributions of each pathway to the overall EI
NOx are displayed in Fig. 13 . The predicted overall EI
NOx was the sum of those calculated using each individual pathway chemistry, with the other pathways deactivated. As shown in Fig. 13, the predicted EI
NOx were kept within high consistency with the experimental results.

As can be seen from cases 1–4, the thermal EI
NOx increased exponentially with
X
O 2
∗
. This was because as Fig. 14 shows, the maximum temperature rise with respect to
T
c o
∗
increased rapidly with the increment in
X
O 2
∗
, especially for cases 3 and 4 whose maximum temperature surpassed 1800 K. On the contrary, as
T
c o
∗
was increased, the thermal EI
NOx increased relatively slowly, due to decrement of the maximum temperature rise with increasing
T
c o
∗
, as Fig. 14 shows. Additionally, being different from the traditional DME jet diffusion flame in which thermal and prompt pathways were dominant [38–40], contribution of the thermal pathway for the DME-MILD flame was fairly ignorable. Just for cases 3, 4, and 6 with the maximum temperature near or above 1800 K, importance of the thermal pathway became remarkable.

Fig. 13 also indicates that the N 2O EI
NOx increased evidently with increasing
X
O 2
∗
. It is analyzed that at a higher
X
O 2
∗
, both flame temperature and O concentration increased, which are favorable for the N 2O-intermediate NO x formation. However due to decrease of the peak temperature rise with increasing
T
c o
∗
( Fig. 14), the N 2O EI
NOx increased rather slowly as
T
c o
∗
was increased.

The NNH EI
NOx decreased slowly with
X
O 2
∗
or
T
c o
∗
, and its contribution to the overall EI
NOx kept nearly constant (50% or so).

To summarize, with regard to the DME-MILD jet diffusion flame, EI
NOx increased gradually with the increment in
X
O 2
∗
or
T
c o
∗
. NO x was generated mainly through the NNH and N 2O pathways; the sum of their contributions exceeded 75% or so.

As Fig. 12 shows, the significant values of NSI
i for (R11)-(R14) in almost every subzone imply a strong NO NO 2 interchange inside the furnace, which resulted in the complex NO/NO 2 configuration as Figs. 9 and 10 show. As displayed in Fig. 15 , the ratio EI
NO2 / EI
NOx increased gradually with the decrease in
X
O 2
∗
or
T
c o
∗
. It is analyzed that the decrease in
X
O 2
∗
or
T
c o
∗
led to depressed flame temperatures, which was favorable for NO-to-NO 2 conversion in the low-temperature zones of FRZ1, PFZ, and RZ. Fig. 15 also demonstrates that for the DME-MILD flame, a considerable fraction of NO was converted to NO 2 finally. EI
NO2 / EI
NOx of case 1 could even reach up to 0.87.

The combustion in most practical combustion systems, like boiler, engine, and turbine, is confined jet flame in configuration. In addition,
T
c o
∗
and
X
O 2
∗
involved in the present experiments are fairly identical with the actual MILD combustion system. Consequently, NO x emission characteristics revealed by this study could be applicable to the practical DME-MILD combustion system adequately.

Table 9 compares the indicated specific NO x emission (ISNO x) of this study with the optimal ones of DME engines reported in the literature. ISNO x evaluates the emitted mass of NO x per 1 kW h thermal output. As shown in Table 9, ISNO x of DME engines varied considerably with engine condition or injection strategy [48–52]. Thomas et al. [50] found that ISNO x decreased nearly linearly with the exhaust gas recirculation (EGR) ratio. At EGR ratio of 30–45%, ISNO x of the DME engines could be reduced to 0.22 g/kW·h, demonstrating that EGR was most efficient to reduce NO x emission. Considering that the MILD condition is often created by EGR, it can be concluded that MILD combustion emits much less NO x than many other engine combustion strategies, such as optimizations of the spray angle, injection timing, and injection strategy, etc. For the DME-MILD flame at
T
C O
∗
= 1200 K and
X
O 2
∗
= 0.040 (case 1), ISNO x could be reduced to 0.071 g/kW·h which is much lower than those of the actual DME engines. Hence, the DME-MILD jet diffusion flame could yield ultra-clean performance.

ce:list-item.ce:para: For the DME-MILD jet flame inside the furnace, NO x was produced or destructed via distinct ways in different subzones: in the low-temperature ( T < 1100 K) zones including FRZ1, PFZ, and RZ, NO was converted to NO 2 via the reverse NO 2 pathways; in the moderate-temperature ( T = 1100–1300 K) zones including FRZ2 and CFZ1, NO 2 was converted to NO via the NO 2 pathways; in the high-temperature ( T = 1300–1700 K) DDFL, NO was reduced via the reverse prompt and reburning pathways, and produced via the N 2O and NNH pathways; in the high-temperature ( T = 1300–1700 K) UDFL, NO was formed via a combination of the NO 2, N 2O, thermal, and prompt pathways; in the ADDFL, NO was generated through a combination of the NO 2, N 2O, NNH, and prompt pathways.

For the DME-MILD jet flame, EI
NOx increased gradually with the increment in
X
O 2
∗
or
T
c o
∗
. NO x was generated mainly through the NNH and N 2O pathways; the sum of their contributions exceeded about 75%. The other pathways were rather unimportant.

A strong NO NO 2 inter-conversion process occurred in the DME-MILD jet flame. The ratio EI
NO2 / EI
NOx could even reach up to 0.87.
The MILD combustion emitted much less NO x than many other engine combustion strategies. The DME-MILD jet flame had ultra-clean performance; its ISNO x could be reduced to 0.071 g/kW·h or so.
